message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a bacterial meningitis and the low glucose level in the CSF indicates bacterial, rather than viral or fungal, cause. Group B Streptococcus is a common cause of meningitis in newborns, especially those born to mothers with poor prenatal care.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is a newborn and the symptoms suggest meningitis. The mother did not receive any prenatal care and had rupture of membranes for more than 18 hours, which puts the newborn at risk for infection with Group B Streptococcus. Cryptococcus neoformans is more common in immunocompromised patients, Enterovirus usually causes mild symptoms in healthy individuals, and Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia but less common for meningitis in newborns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest bacterial meningitis, and the most common organism causing bacterial meningitis in neonates is Group B Streptococcus. Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal organism and not commonly seen in neonates. Enterovirus and Streptococcus pneumoniae may cause meningitis, but they are not as common in neonates as Group B Streptococcus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of fever, irritability, poor feeding, pleocytosis, and low glucose level in the cerebrospinal fluid suggests meningitis. Group B Streptococcus is a common cause of early-onset neonatal meningitis, especially in babies whose mothers did not receive prenatal care. Cryptococcus neoformans is more commonly causing meningitis in immunocompromised patients. Enterovirus and Streptococcus pneumoniae are also causes of meningitis, but they are less common in neonates.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest neonatal meningitis, and the low glucose level in the cerebrospinal fluid confirms the diagnosis. Among the options, Group B Streptococcus is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis. Enterovirus can cause aseptic meningitis but the glucose level is usually normal. Cryptococcus neoformans and Streptococcus pneumoniae are rare causes of neonatal meningitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the patient’s age and symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is neonatal sepsis. The mother did not receive any prenatal care and had rupture of membranes prior to delivery, increasing the risk of infection. Group B Streptococcus is a common cause of neonatal sepsis and fits the clinical presentation. Cryptococcus neoformans is more commonly associated with meningitis in immunocompromised patients. Enterovirus can cause meningitis but is less common in neonates. Streptococcus pneumoniae is uncommon in neonates and more commonly causes pneumonia or meningitis in older children and adults.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest meningitis. The history of inadequate prenatal care and rupture of membranes suggest that the causative organism is likely to be acquired during delivery. The most common organism causing neonatal meningitis is Group B Streptococcus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and CSF findings suggest meningitis. Newborns are particularly susceptible to Group B Streptococcus infections, which can result from maternal colonization. Cryptococcus neoformans primarily affects immunocompromised patients, Enteroviruses typically do not cause bacterial meningitis-like symptoms, and Streptococcus pneumoniae usually causes meningitis in older patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including fever and a pleocytosis in the cerebrospinal fluid, suggest bacterial meningitis. Group B Streptococcus is a common cause of bacterial meningitis in neonates. The other options are not commonly associated with neonatal meningitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab findings suggest bacterial meningitis, and Group B Streptococcus is a common cause of meningitis in neonates. Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal infection and Enterovirus is a viral infection, neither of which are likely in this case. Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause meningitis, but it is less common in neonates than Group B Streptococcus.
